text: Yes, when the F comes I can have a longer commute with a 10 minute walk on both ends, an already horribly overcrowded platform and overcrowded A/C line that will be even worse w more ppl like me forced to take it. I don’t want that. That’s my point.

text: Yes I could be forced to take 3 trains to get to work, which means 2 transfers a whole other line that fucks up my commute if it goes down. That sounds awful. That’s my point. Why would anyone want such a thing?

text: But if the R doesn’t run between BK and Manhattan it might as well not run at all for many commuters. I’m sure the Franklin Ave shuttle has a great on time rate because it only goes a mile. But that doesn’t mean we should chop every line into little segments.

text: More people will be inconvenienced by not being able to get to Manhattan on their line, having to transfer an extra time, and not being dropped nearly as close to their destination. My office is on top of Rector, 10 minute walk from Fulton, and A/C platform and trains are packed
author: badler

text: Changing trains at Jay St is atrocious. I could take the F to the A/C at Jay, but the platform and trains are so crowded I never do. Now I'll have no choice, and I'll be a 10 minute further walk from my office because I'll have to walk from Fulton instead of Rector
author: badler

text: I've got an even more outside the box idea, so bear with me: What about, instead of shutting down service between BK and Manhattan, we improve transit reliability through infrastructure improvements and signal modernization that we all know is needed?

text: I understand this: "Tenants of that new building would have driven up rents or moved further away." It's correct argument for why new construction restrains price increases in existing housing stock & should be allowed. It's not proof that new buildings themselves are affordable
author: badler

text: For the last time: they aren't affordable. That's just a false premise. You think $3,100/month for a 1br is affordable? I never could afford that myself. I also can't afford most suburban mcmansions and I also think they are ugly.

text: sure, that's fair, but would you like to argue that either those buildings from the 60s on my block or the brand new one are tastefully done? that they couldn't possibly have been done better?
author: badler

text: Do I? No, I was hoping to get some. Instead, I mostly got a lot of derisive dismissal of aesthetic considerations, unsubstantiated assertions that aesthetic complaints are pretext and demonstrably false claims that I opposed density and infill multifamily TOD
author: badler

text: Right, I never was able to afford Manhattan at all. I wish that new buildings in my price range weren't so ugly. But I still think your class argument is backwards, as these buildings with fancy new amenities are more expensive than those around them in all cities.
author: badler

text: Yes, I'm aware. Most new development since WWII has been ugly, IMO.
author: badler

text: I'm aware of that, which is why I favor making new multifamily housing more popular. But aesthetics isn't always an excuse for exclusion: sometimes it's the actual concern & exclusion the unfortunate byproduct. Esp in liberal urban neighborhoods. So why not address that?
author: badler

text: Well, they aren't generic, cookie-cutter, ticky-tacky. Also, your econ premise abt "working ppl" is weird. These generic new buildings are typically expensive. E.g. This ugly one on my block has apts 50% more expensive than the neighborhood avg
author: badler

text: I live in a house identical to the second one on the right (brick facade). While no masterpiece, I think it's quite charming. The infill on the left is a good example of how newer, denser mid-rise development (a good thing!) is needlessly ugly IMO. Look at that crazy staircase!

text: Oversupply caused many to go unsold in the crash. But my point is that new buildings that are nice on the inside and ugly on the outside might be sold but still trigger opposition. The ugliness is literally an externality.
author: badler

text: Apartments in that building are the most expensive in my neighborhood. Look at that listing I showed you. It's $3,099/month for a 1br, probably 50% above neighborhood avg. And I'm sure putting that ugly house in your photo in many urban neighborhoods would trigger complaints

text: Right, and I'm saying I'm insulted that after 15 years of covering urban planning I'd have to answer that question instead of you, I dunno, googling me

text: That's a seriously obnoxious question. You think I've never been to a planning commission hearing? Why don't you google my work before casting ignorant aspersions on it
author: badler

text: It's funny because you just lazily assume I'm never written in favor of these things, when five seconds with google would show that I've advocated eliminating parking requirements and relaxed building codes. It's not an "admission" on my part, it's a staunchly held belief.
author: badler

text: I'm suggesting that a good policy, density, would be aided by making it more appealing to its neighbors. I've never "bashed" density. It's sad that you're so unable to actually wrestle with aesthetic critiques of new developments and so hostile to the suggestion that you try.
author: badler

text: That's a very ignorant misreading of my tweet. If you googled me and any phrase like housing, you'd see I've spent 15 years writing about the benefits of density. The house in that photo is ugly and wasteful and I'd hate to see it crop up on my block

text: Not sure I follow that. New Urbanist architects have lots of commissions, their developments are expensive, showing high demand. So what says otherwise?

text: Silly analogy. "Saying trump supporters have economic anxiety" has been disproved by rigorous sociology and poli sci studies demonstrating Trump support is predicted by racial animus, not econ precarity. Do you have such a study showing no one actual cares about aesthetics?

text: Sure, I make all the arguments in favor of allowing development that you're familiar with - econ justice, enviro, racial integration, public health, econ efficiency etc - and never once suggest - as you falsely accuse me of doing - that these buildings should be illegal.
author: badler

text: Also, if you're familiar with the economics of housing, you're aware that the cost of building and maintaining housing is simply too high for the v low-income to cover it unsubsidized. People who are at risk of homelessness are saved by govt programs, not market-rate development
author: badler

text: As you know, if you're remotely familiar with my work, I agree that "buildings like these are a good tool" for solving society's housing shortage writ large. I don't know why the fact that are ugly, soulless, generic has to be defended as opposed to improved upon. Do you?
